content.description:
A nice easy multi pitch trad line that will take you to the top of the cliff.
Pitch 1 - Climb up the steep but big juggy holds staying on the outside corner/arete up to a ledge with a pine tree. Continue up and slightly left. Look for a big flake overhead. Make one or two 5.6 moves to reach the top of the flake. Belay off the birch tree or nice boulder pinch.  90 feet
Pitch 2 - Move up and left off the belay to an inside corner and wide crack. Climb up this corner system until you are on top of the feature. Step up to a right trending ramp which leads to a nice belay ledge and bolted anchor. 80 feet 5.5
Pitch 3 - Two options here. From the bolted anchor move left to climb the top half of Andrea (5.5) or move right to climb the top pitch of Choss Factory at 5.8. 60 feet Both options are equally good. 

Go to the left end of Border Wall then move up about 8 feet to gain a big ledge. Flake your rope here and then start up the corner.
Single rack to 4" piece. Rap the route or walk off.

climbs.name: Choss Factory
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Shawn Bethune, July 2019

content.description:
If it were not for gravely ledges and some poor rock quality this route would be quite nice. It's still worth doing but beware of pitch 2 which has a section at the top of chossy rock. Very doable but scary as shit.
Pitch 1 - Two starts available. A very nice steep fist crack is available to the right of the corner or start to the left at the corner. This pitch has good rock quality with plenty of gear available. Tree anchor. 80 feet.
Pitch 2 - Move up a sandy sloping ledge to a nice hand crack. Gain another ledge system. Optional belay here at a tree or continue up a face. The face starts out quite good. Lots of gear, nice climbing but when you get ten feet from the next ledge the rock turns to crap. The climbing is easy but the rock is not really protectable and it could break off in your hands. Gain the next ledge and belay at a bolted anchor. 90 feet
Pitch 3 - From the bolts move slightly right.  A fixed pin protects the moves off the belay then good gear to the top of the wall. This last pitch is excellent. It has good rock quality and excellent movement. Tree anchor. 60 feet

Far left side of Border Wall. 
Single rack to 3. You will want a #4 to protect the opening moves if you choose the alt start to the right. Tree and bolted anchors. Rap the route.

Pleasant climbing past flakes and horizontals to a tree anchor.

At the right end of Border Wall, left of the low roof area.
single rack to BD #1. Tree anchor

Good quality rock and solid pro throughout. Nice, easy route to the top of the cliff.
Pitch 1 - Start on the left side of the face, about 5 feet left of Up, Up and Away. Fun climbing on jugs to a ledge. Step right after gaining the ledge, then up and left through a flake to another ledge. Belay off gear anchor or continue up through 3rd class terrain to a tree anchor.
Pitch 2 - From the tree anchor go up an left to a left facing corner system. Climb the corner to a series of ledges that leads to a final steep but short wall. Rappel from here or climb the last pitch of North of the Border to reach the top of the cliff.

Middle of the wall. Just left of Up, Up and Away. 
Single rack to 3. Tree anchors.

climbs.name: North of The Border
climbs.fa: G. Hughes, M. Couturier, E. Couturier

content.description:
Nice easy 3 pitch route to the top of the cliff. 

Pitch 1 - Climb Up, Up and Away to the big pine tree. Step left then up for about 15 meters of 4th and low 5th class. Stop at the base of a steep featured wall next to a spruce tree with a chain on it. Belay here. 30 meters

Pitch 2 - Ascend the steep wall to a large tiered ledge. Choose a tree and belay. 20 meters

Pitch 3 - Move the belay up to the base of the final wall. The last pitch starts a bit left going up and slightly left then back right. There are two options for the top out - straight up is harder but with loads of gear. Right has less gear but is quite easy. Finish on a pine tree with a chain around it. 20 meters

Rap the route or walk off. The second rappel is a rope stretcher with a 60 meter rope so pay close attention and tie knots in the ends of your rope. 

This would be a great first multi pitch for the aspiring trad leader. It has many rests from which to place gear, is well protected with low commitment level. The climbing is never difficult but always fun. 



Middle of Border Wall. 


Single rack to 3. Tree anchors with chains. Rap the route.

climbs.name: Tierra Del Falco
climbs.fa: L. Toron, K. MacLellan, G. Hughes 2010

content.description:
About 4m right of the final vertical headwall pitch of North of the Border, climb the obvious crack/flake. Step left at the top and finish on the same tree as North of the Border.



Located on the final little headwall at the top of Border Wall. To access it, climb North of the Border to the large ledge before its final pitch.

A few cams to #3 BD. Tree anchor

The most obvious line in the middle of the wall. 

Located directly below the larger Pine tree on the ledge at the top of the pitch. 
Single rack to 3" piece. Tree anchor. Rap the route or walk off.

climbs.name: Wildlings
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Kate Trecartin, July 2019

content.description:
This is a three pitch route that takes you to the top of the cliff or you can just climb the first pitch. The first pitch is easily top roped.
Pitch 1 - Take one of two starts, each are about 50 feet in length and lead to their own separate bolted anchor. Would be way better if it were not for the ledges.
Pitch 2 - Gain the ledge above the anchor and head through 4th class terrain up slightly right aiming for a steep section with a short fist/hand crack. Climb the crack to a slab. Make thoughtful moves onto a bolt protected slab then easy climbing on jugs to a bolted anchor at the base of the last wall.
Pitch 3 - Climb the last pitch of Choss Factory or North of The Border.

Left hand side of Border Wall.
Single rack to 3" piece. Bolted anchors. One protection bolt on pitch 2.

This wall is often overlooked. Situated between Waterfall Wall and Minke. It has good quality rock, good single pitch and multi pitch climbs. It is an excellent area for new trad leaders as the routes are quite moderate with good pro.
